 [![COMPNOR-approved propaganda poster by Resinu Santhe-Caltra](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/2/23/StrengthAndObedience-SWPropaganda.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20161214212040) [![COMPNOR-approved propaganda poster by Resinu Santhe-Caltra](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/2/23/StrengthAndObedience-SWPropaganda.jpg/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/200?cb=20161214212040)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/2/23/StrengthAndObedience-SWPropaganda.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20161214212040) 

COMPNOR-approved propaganda poster by Resinu Santhe-Caltra

 

Acquiring much of the galactic communications systems from the former Galactic Republic, the Empire nationalized the HoloNet News and its galaxy-spanning broadcasts and hyperspace-powered communication systems. The new [Imperial Holovision](/wiki/Imperial_Holovision "Imperial Holovision") was overseen by the Ministry of Information, who in tandem with the Imperial Press Corps, ensured reporting stayed in line with "acceptable" news coverage and government policy.[[255]](#cite_note-DB-255)[[256]](#cite_note-Special_Report-256)[[254]](#cite_note-HoloNet_News_Report_Press_Corps-254) While the Imperial holoNet was the only state-sanctioned news agency, local news outlets that supported the Galactic Empire were allowed to remain.[[257]](#cite_note-Fight_the_Empire-257) Those that attempted to distribute independent publications could be imprisoned without term.[[87]](#cite_note-Lost_Stars-87) It was also law that the Imperial HoloNet be broadcast at all times in every drinking establishment.[[18]](#cite_note-Empire_Day_ep-18)

As expected, the galactic HoloNet remained one of the most-viewed news stations in the galaxy, forming public opinion and reporting on pro-Imperial issues and events. When military objectives trumped civilian information, the Empire shut down the local HoloNet in varying sectors, and prioritized HoloNet transmissions to the military, giving Palpatine and his armed forces near-instantaneous communication across the entire galaxy.[[18]](#cite_note-Empire_Day_ep-18)[[9]](#cite_note-Tarkin-9) The Empire even turned leisure activities, such as sports broadcasts, into extensions of its will: the popular [grav-ball](/wiki/Grav-ball "Grav-ball") sport was turned into little more than a recruitment tool for the Empire during its rule.[[258]](#cite_note-ForceofSports-258) Following the Battle of Endor, the New Republic abolished the Empire's restrictions and censorship on HoloNet and encouraged the creation of several HoloNet channels including the [Queen of the Core Network](/wiki/Queen_of_the_Core_Network "Queen of the Core Network") to win over the galactic public after it assumed control by 5 ABY.[[16]](#cite_note-Aftermath-16)

#### Controlling history[]

:   "*The Empire's been erasing the Jedi from history, step by step. First they said the Jedi tried to murder the last chancellor—Palpatine, before he was Emperor—in some sort of coup at the war's end. It's what I grew up hearing.*"  
    "*I heard that version from the older officers. It never made any sense because—*"  
    "*Because you were taught there weren't many Jedi to begin with, right? That they were relics, mostly forgotten? That's the trouble when they keep changing the story. Nah, there were thousands of them, and real influential in the Republic. Believe me, you hear a lot about the legend of the Jedi and the Force when you join the Rebel Alliance.*"  
    "*How do you know it's not all propaganda on your—on the rebel side?*"  
    "*I don't. That's the nasty thing about the Emperor changing history. Leaves you doubting, doesn't it?*"
:   ―[Nath Tensent](/wiki/Nath_Tensent "Nath Tensent") and [Yrica Quell](/wiki/Yrica_Quell "Yrica Quell")[[48]](#cite_note-Alphabet_Squadron-48)

In order to secure the "unlimited power"[[259]](#cite_note-POV_225-259) he so desperately longed for,[[3]](#cite_note-Episode_III-3) Palpatine's empire needed to take control of knowledge through the spread of information[[259]](#cite_note-POV_225-259) and manipulation of how history was taught.[[48]](#cite_note-Alphabet_Squadron-48) For example, in regards to the Jedi Order and its systematic eradication, Palpatine had openly branded the Jedi Order as traitors[[259]](#cite_note-POV_225-259) since the declaration of his regime,[[3]](#cite_note-Episode_III-3) and subsequent propaganda spread via the Imperial-controlled HoloNet maintained that image.[[259]](#cite_note-POV_225-259) In a rally held during the first days of the Imperial Era, Grand Vizier Mas Amedda claimed that the Jedi had been behind the "Separatists plots" that had so recently rocked the galaxy, but he promised Palpatine had seen through their lies to deliver the galaxy into a new age of freedom.[[43]](#cite_note-Darth_Vader_(2017)_1-43) Imperial propaganda painted the Jedi as traitors who had subverted democracy, disrupted peace, and caused the Clone Wars with their strange abilities[[42]](#cite_note-Crimson_Reign_3-42) in an effort to usurp control of the galaxy for themselves.[[3]](#cite_note-Episode_III-3) The aim of the Empire was to purge the Jedi from the memories and thoughts of its citizens beyond just wiping out its remaining members.[[42]](#cite_note-Crimson_Reign_3-42)

 [![Madelin Sun reflects on the Galactic Empire's manipulation and corruption of history.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/8/8d/ImperialControlHistory-CrimsonReign3.png/revision/latest?cb=20240913214521) [![Madelin Sun reflects on the Galactic Empire's manipulation and corruption of history.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/8/8d/ImperialControlHistory-CrimsonReign3.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/300?cb=20240913214521)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/8/8d/ImperialControlHistory-CrimsonReign3.png/revision/latest?cb=20240913214521) 

Madelin Sun reflects on the Galactic Empire's manipulation and corruption of history.

 

As noted by [Lyra Erso](/wiki/Lyra_Erso "Lyra Erso"), the Jedi seemed to vanish from galactic memory and enter myth over the course of a few weeks, with very little grief towards the people who had once protected the Republic.[[56]](#cite_note-Catalyst-56) The historian [Madelin Sun](/wiki/The_Archivist "The Archivist") believed that the Empire's successful suppression of the Jedi was an example of its rule by fear. As she reasoned, beyond Palpatine preying on peoples' fears by claiming the Jedi were traitors who had started the war, the Jedi Order appeared to embody their best selves, which reminded the galaxy at large that they were not their own best selves: for how much people loved the Jedi at one time, they also hated the Jedi for reminding them of that. Sun also believed that the Empire exploited its willingness to kill, imprison its citizens, and deploy its massive military in the campaign to eradicate the Jedi from memory. By simply passing laws to outlaw the Jedi, help the Jedi, use the Force, or even know about it, the Empire generated a fear of implied force in its population. After wiping out those who were willing to die for their beliefs, those who survived were people who, in their fear, just wanted to get by and so would not pass down knowledge of the Jedi. To Sun, the Jedi were not "forgotten" but instead became a de facto thought crime punishable by death. With no one willing to speak of the Jedi, knowledge of the Order largely died off in a generation.[[42]](#cite_note-Crimson_Reign_3-42) With the Order's reputation ruined[[259]](#cite_note-POV_225-259) and existence all but covered up as a thought crime,[[42]](#cite_note-Crimson_Reign_3-42) the Empire was able to reshape history by altering documents[[259]](#cite_note-POV_225-259) and how history was taught,[[48]](#cite_note-Alphabet_Squadron-48) reshaping history itself to its designs and leaving the Jedi to be regarded as "outlaws"[[259]](#cite_note-POV_225-259) who were supposedly small in number.[[48]](#cite_note-Alphabet_Squadron-48)

Palpatine also claimed the Jedi Temple as the Imperial Palace,[[259]](#cite_note-POV_225-259) transforming a once-major Jedi building into a symbol of the Empire[[260]](#cite_note-Jedi_Temple_DB-260) and claiming control of the Jedi Archives, whose contents could have challenged anti-Jedi propaganda.[[259]](#cite_note-POV_225-259) As per Palpatine's claims in the Proclamation of the New Order,[[3]](#cite_note-Episode_III-3) the Empire's initial history of the Clone Wars held that Jedi "mystics" launched a coup and attacked Palpatine, only to be defeated. Their conspiracy, according to the propagandized history, forced Palpatine to transform the Republic into the Empire. However, younger Imperials were taught a version of history that minimized the role of the Jedi, painting them as relics of a bygone time and a small-scale cult during the Republic's final years. One Imperial citizen who grew up with that version of the story, [Yrica Quell](/wiki/Yrica_Quell "Yrica Quell"), sometimes heard the prior claims from older Imperial officers, creating confusion in her mind because she had been raised on the idea the Jedi were much less important. The history taught to Quell also claimed that Palpatine promised to create a better future out of a corrupt, decayed republic, with Quell believing he had succeeded; according to the history she was taught, there was a reduction of petty crime and corporate influence in the wake of Palpatine's rise to power, with local governments also forced into the Imperial hierarchy if they hurt or failed their populous. However, even Quell heard people say Palpatine had been militarizing the Republic to grab power, with everything that came in its wake a mere side effect of his personal ambition.[[48]](#cite_note-Alphabet_Squadron-48)

Indeed, different forms of Imperial propaganda could contradict each other; beyond the example of trying to limit the Jedi Order's role in history,[[48]](#cite_note-Alphabet_Squadron-48) some narratives[[9]](#cite_note-Tarkin-9) painted the Jedi as the creators of the Confederacy of Independent Systems[[43]](#cite_note-Darth_Vader_(2017)_1-43)—having used the supposedly "former" Jedi Dooku to form the Separatist state[[9]](#cite_note-Tarkin-9)—as part of their supposed coup to overthrow the Republic,[[43]](#cite_note-Darth_Vader_(2017)_1-43) whereas other Imperial claims separated the Jedi and CIS, depicting the Jedi as merely using the war to grab at power and turning Dooku into a lone figure[[46]](#cite_note-MaskFear-46) who acted out of "craven ambition."[[45]](#cite_note-Leia-45) Even still, Dooku's known status as a former Jedi helped to sell the image that the entire Order could have betrayed the Republic.[[5]](#cite_note-Propaganda-5) While the idea that the Jedi had created the Clone Wars was a central[[42]](#cite_note-Crimson_Reign_3-42) and foundational piece of Imperial propaganda,[[44]](#cite_note-Launchpad229-44) some citizens expressed a hate for the Jedi on the belief that the Order had failed to prevent or effectively the win the war. Nonetheless, their cries of hatred had the same result as those who believed in the story of Jedi betrayal.[[46]](#cite_note-MaskFear-46)

### Science and technology[]

:   [![icon](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/04/Blue_Glass_Arrow.svg/revision/latest?cb=20090726033133) Main articles: [Imperial Department of Military Research](/wiki/Imperial_Department_of_Military_Research "Imperial Department of Military Research"), [Imperial Military Department of Advanced Weapons Research](/wiki/Imperial_Military_Department_of_Advanced_Weapons_Research "Imperial Military Department of Advanced Weapons Research") and [Imperial Corps of Bioengineers](/wiki/Imperial_Corps_of_Bioengineers "Imperial Corps of Bioengineers")

:   "*The universe is old. We are running out of time. I desire progress...*"
:   ―Doctor Cylo-V[[261]](#cite_note-Darth_Vader_5-261)

 [![The Death Star was one of the Empire's greatest engineering projects.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/55/DS1DeathStar-TSWB.png/revision/latest?cb=20210301050003) [![The Death Star was one of the Empire's greatest engineering projects.](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/55/DS1DeathStar-TSWB.png/revision/latest/scale-to-width-down/300?cb=20210301050003)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/5/55/DS1DeathStar-TSWB.png/revision/latest?cb=20210301050003) 

The Death Star was one of the Empire's greatest engineering projects.

 

One of the Empire's most [ambitious scientific developments](/wiki/Project_Stardust "Project Stardust") was the Death Star, a moon-sized, deep-[space](/wiki/Realspace "Realspace") mobile [battle station](/wiki/Battle_station "Battle station") designed to fire a single planet-destroying superlaser powered by massive [kyber crystals](/wiki/Kyber_crystal "Kyber crystal") and built in [orbit](/wiki/Orbit "Orbit") of Geonosis. Started by the Galactic Republic during the Clone Wars and continued under the leadership of Krennic, who oversaw the [Imperial Military Department of Advanced Weapons Research](/wiki/Imperial_Military_Department_of_Advanced_Weapons_Research "Imperial Military Department of Advanced Weapons Research"), which was responsible for the completion of the long-delayed project, this was supported by a complex logistical network of bases.[[4]](#cite_note-R1VD-4)

The Empire was also believed to have created many other superweapons, such as the [*Onager*-class Star Destroyer](/wiki/Onager-class_Star_Destroyer "Onager-class Star Destroyer"), a type of [capital ship](/wiki/Capital_ship "Capital ship") that utilized a kyber-crystal superweapon; the [Mass Shadow Generator](/wiki/Mass_Shadow_Generator "Mass Shadow Generator"), which was rumored to exist in realspace and hyperspace; the [Torpedo Sphere](/wiki/Torpedo_Sphere "Torpedo Sphere"), a [siege platform](/wiki/Siege_platform "Siege platform") and space station; or the rumored [Asteroid Dreadnought](/wiki/Asteroid_Dreadnought "Asteroid Dreadnought"), which was camouflaged as [space rock](/wiki/Asteroid "Asteroid"); the [Omega Frost](/wiki/Omega_Frost "Omega Frost"), an interstellar freeze ray; and the [Electro-Proton Bomb/Defoliator](/wiki/Electro-Proton_Bomb/Defoliator "Electro-Proton Bomb/Defoliator"), which was based on the Republic's [electro-proton bomb](/wiki/Electro-proton_bomb "Electro-proton bomb") from the Clone Wars.[[214]](#cite_note-Rebel_Files-214) The [Dark trooper program](/wiki/Dark_Trooper_project "Dark Trooper project"), deemed a failure, led to the Empire's disillusionment with battle droids.[[12]](#cite_note-Dawn-12)

[Operation: Cinder](/wiki/Operation:_Cinder "Operation: Cinder") oversaw the use of [climate disruption arrays](/wiki/Climate_disruption_array "Climate disruption array"), which were [satellites](/wiki/Satellite "Satellite") modified to provoke storms once the beam reached through the [planet](/wiki/Planet "Planet").[[167]](#cite_note-Battlefront_II-167)

Experimental starships including the TIE/IN interceptor and TIE/D Defender pushed the Empire's technical capabilities, and introduced concepts and technology that would be reincorporated in future ship designs throughout the New Republic Era.[[262]](#cite_note-TLJ:ICS-262)

A group of *[Sith scientists](/wiki/Sith_scientist "Sith scientist")* used [alchemy](/wiki/Sith_alchemy "Sith alchemy") and science to develop Project Blackwing, to achieve immortality, with the project being based out of a [secret research facility](/wiki/Research_facility_(Blackwing) "Research facility (Blackwing)") on Dandoran. However, the project went awry when a virus known as "the Sickness" was accidentally created and killed its hosts, turning their bodies into intelligent cannibalistic [zombies](/wiki/Zombie "Zombie") known as [Undead Troopers](/wiki/Undead_Trooper "Undead Trooper").[[263]](#cite_note-SWC-263) Imperial scientists working on [Project Celestial Power](/wiki/Project_Celestial_Power "Project Celestial Power") also tried to contain [dark-matter](/wiki/Dark_matter "Dark matter") [quintessence](/wiki/Quintessence "Quintessence").[[214]](#cite_note-Rebel_Files-214)

The Emperor himself had planned to further push the boundaries of what could be accomplished without the Force, creating cybernetically enhanced supersoldiers under the development of Doctor Cylo at his heavily guarded [research base](/wiki/Cylo%27s_base "Cylo's base"). Owing to Vader's failure to protect both the first Death Star and Weapons Factory Alpha, Palpatine planned to eventually form an army of cybernetic soldiers as his primary enforcers, reducing Vader's position as apprentice to a mere ceremonial role.[[261]](#cite_note-Darth_Vader_5-261)

The [Imperial Mining Institute](/wiki/Imperial_Mining_Institute "Imperial Mining Institute") also existed under the New Order, while the Imperial Department of Military Research helped boost the combat forces of the Empire, developing the widely used stormtrooper armor and the [IT-O Interrogation Unit](/wiki/IT-O_interrogation_droid "IT-O interrogation droid"), along with the [9D9-s54 Dianoga spy droid](/wiki/9D9-s54_Dianoga_spy_droid "9D9-s54 Dianoga spy droid").[[52]](#cite_note-Rebels_Visual_Guide-52)[[264]](#cite_note-RB-264) The Empire also initiated [Project Harvester](/wiki/Project_Harvester "Project Harvester"), a clandestine operation designed to root out children with Force sensitivity and detain them at an underground facility connected to the [Arkanis Academy](/wiki/Arkanis_Academy "Arkanis Academy"), located on the Outer Rim world of Arkanis.[[265]](#cite_note-Rebel_in_the_Ranks-265)

## Society and culture[]

### Overview[]

:   [![icon](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIABAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAEALAAAAAABAAEAQAICTAEAOw%3D%3D)](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/04/Blue_Glass_Arrow.svg/revision/latest?cb=20090726033133) Main articles: [Xenophobia](/wiki/Xenophobia "Xenophobia"), [Anti-droid sentiment](/wiki/Anti-droid_sentiment "Anti-droid sentiment"), [New Order](/wiki/New_Order "New Order"), [High Human](/wiki/High_Human "High Human") and [Brutalist (architecture)](/wiki/Brutalist_(architecture) "Brutalist (architecture)")

:   "*Can you stop thinking of yourself as a native of your home planet and begin thinking of yourself as an Imperial first? An Imperial only? Can you accept that protecting and serving the world you came from is best accomplished by strengthening the Empire to which it belongs?*"
:   ―The introductory speech at the [Royal Imperial Academy](/wiki/Royal_Imperial_Academy "Royal Imperial Academy") on [Coruscant](/wiki/Coruscant "Coruscant")[[87]](#cite_note-Lost_Stars-87)

The transition from the Republic to the Empire was also marked by major changes in the new government's architectural aesthetic. While the democratic government favored sweeping lines in [its architecture](/wiki/Republic_architecture "Republic architecture"), Palpatine's authoritarian regime preferred bold and [brutalist](/wiki/Brutalist_(architecture) "Brutalist (architecture)") designs.[[4]](#cite_note-R1VD-4) Palpatine himself enjoyed the look of such architecture due to the brutal nature it embodied.[[266]](#cite_note-Dark_Lord_21-266) This brutalist style first emerged before the foundation of the Empire during the Clone Wars, when the [architect](/wiki/Architect "Architect") Orson Krennic transformed the municipal grounds on Coruscant into military command centers.[[4]](#cite_note-R1VD-4) A prime example of Krennic's work was the [Republic Center for Military Operations](/wiki/Imperial_Inspectorate_HQ "Imperial Inspectorate HQ").[[56]](#cite_note-Catalyst-56)

Meanwhile, the [ISB Central Office](/wiki/ISB_Central_Office "ISB Central Office") on Coruscant broke from the trend of darky colored Imperial installations with white conference rooms and hallways, possibly reflecting a degree of "ideological purity."[[267]](#cite_note-World_Building-267) [Grav-ball](/wiki/Grav-ball "Grav-ball") was a popular sport within the Galactic Empire, with many worlds hosting teams that occasionally competed with one another.[[218]](#cite_note-Edge_of_the_Galaxy-218) Underground gladiatorial games existed within Imperial territories, the [Outer Rim Carve-up](/wiki/Outer_Rim_Carve-up "Outer Rim Carve-up") and [Stormblade Bloodfest](/wiki/Stormblade_Bloodfest "Stormblade Bloodfest") being some of the organized occurrences of the sport within the early years of the Empire.[[238]](#cite_note-Ezra's_Gamble-238)

Humanocentric single-species domination was not coincidental, but intended[[7]](#cite_note-Aftermath_LD-7) under the [High Human](/wiki/High_Human "High Human") cultural model.[[26]](#cite_note-TROS_VD-26) Imperial propaganda actively supported state-sponsored ethnocentric [xenophobia](/wiki/Xenophobia "Xenophobia") and fear-mongering. To the Empire, "aliens" were by and large unwelcome within its order, with aliens being seen as "different" and "strange." As such, the Empire treated nonhuman segments of its populations as serfs, slaves, or obstacles needing to be tamed, removed, or ignored. The Empire supported the idea that aliens were untrustworthy—unlike humans—and behind their veneer of innocence lurked a vicious monster. The Imperial propaganda machine was so effective in its message that even near-human species exhibited an inherent distrust towards nonhuman populations.[[7]](#cite_note-Aftermath_LD-7) Since the Empire looked down on aliens, it was rare for aliens to serve as Imperial officers.[[52]](#cite_note-Rebels_Visual_Guide-52) Nevertheless, some nonhumans were known to occupy lofty roles within the Empire, such as the [Chagrian](/wiki/Chagrian "Chagrian") Mas Amedda, who served as the Empire's Grand Vizier,[[9]](#cite_note-Tarkin-9) the Imperial Grand Admiral Thrawn,[[114]](#cite_note-Steps_Into_Shadow-114) and the [Pau'an](/wiki/Pau%27an "Pau'an") Grand Inquisitor, the leading figure in the Inquisitorius during the Age of the Empire.[[66]](#cite_note-Always_Two_There_Are-66)

Still, Thrawn noticed that he faced adversity due to his non-human origins and the fact that he was not linked to a major political family.[[268]](#cite_note-Thrawn:_Alliances-268) One of the main origins of the anti-alien belief was that during the [Clone Wars](/wiki/Clone_Wars "Clone Wars") most of the [separatist leaders](/wiki/Confederacy_of_Independent_Systems "Confederacy of Independent Systems") were aliens from sectors far from the [Core Worlds](/wiki/Core_Worlds "Core Worlds"). That made the [humans](/wiki/Human "Human") distrustful of the other [species](/wiki/Species "Species") of [the galaxy](/wiki/The_galaxy "The galaxy") during the [Imperial Era](/wiki/Imperial_Era "Imperial Era").[[223]](#cite_note-Thrawn-223) In addition to state-sponsored discrimination against a predominantly nonhuman galaxy, the Empire discouraged the learning of alien languages and cultures such as [Ithorese](/wiki/Ithorese "Ithorese") in an effort to destroy foreign cultures, and sought to impose high "Imperial standards" for its citizens.[[16]](#cite_note-Aftermath-16) The destructive nature of the Clone Wars and use of droid armies by the Separatist Alliance fostered and expounded anti-droid bigotry so well into the galactic psyche that it would endure well into the Imperial Era.[[5]](#cite_note-Propaganda-5)

The Empire saw droids as servants and tools, to be discarded and thrown away when no longer useful.[[7]](#cite_note-Aftermath_LD-7) The Galactic Empire was not only xenophobic towards the alien species of the galaxy, but some Imperial officers displayed similar sentiment towards human groups whom they deemed to be of lesser social standing. Some human Imperial officers, especially those from the Core Worlds, displayed disrespect towards humans who hailed from regions like [Wild Space](/wiki/Wild_Space "Wild Space")[[223]](#cite_note-Thrawn-223) and the Outer Rim, including Lothal.[[269]](#cite_note-Fighter_Flight-269) The Empire also turned against the Mandalorians, who rejected Imperial leadership and thus were targeted for extermination.[[270]](#cite_note-Chapter_16-270) The [clones](/wiki/Cloning "Cloning") of the planet [Kamino](/wiki/Kamino "Kamino") also began to be discriminated against by the Empire after they were seen as relics of the Old Republic that were no longer useful and could be discarded,[[16]](#cite_note-Aftermath-16) causing many ex-clone soldiers to become unemployed.[[271]](#cite_note-Part_II-271)

The Imperial education system emphasized science through initiatives for the youth.[[12]](#cite_note-Dawn-12)[[97]](#cite_note-Imperial_Registration_Program-97)[[49]](#cite_note-Twilight_Company-49)[[139]](#cite_note-Heir-139) Many Imperials with a good education knew two or three of the more commonly spoken languages.[[272]](#cite_note-Inferno_Squad-272)

### Demographics[]

:   "*The Empire improves every system it touches. Judge by any metric. Safety, prosperity, trade, opportunity, peace. Compare Imperial rule to what is happening now.*"
:   ―The Client[[184]](#cite_note-Chapter_3-184)

As a pan-galactic Empire, the Empire was home to countless alien species across the galaxy. In terms of preference, the population of the Empire was dominated largely by humans, a species native to the Imperial capital world Coruscant.[[64]](#cite_note-Uprising-64) Humans were the most common species in both the Imperial Military and the Empire's political circles, with the highest echelons of the New Order almost entirely consisting of the species.[[273]](#cite_note-Epic_Battles-273)

To increase the human population and military manpower, several Imperial breeding programs were enacted in the early days of the Empire. They encouraged people to start and grow families, and rewarded them for it. While the Empire supported traditional heterosexual relationships, it did not care about the individual sexual preferences of its citizens, provided that such individuals kept their affairs behind closed doors, and did not interfere with any of its family programs.[[7]](#cite_note-Aftermath_LD-7)

As a human-dominated government, the Galactic Empire supported [Galactic Basic Standard](/wiki/Galactic_Basic_Standard "Galactic Basic Standard") and its [Aurebesh](/wiki/Aurebesh "Aurebesh")/[High Galactic](/wiki/High_Galactic "High Galactic") writing system. Learning of foreign languages and cultures for the general populace was disapproved of.[[16]](#cite_note-Aftermath-16)

Officially, all organized religion and belief in the supernatural was outlawed.[[17]](#cite_note-TFA_VD-17) In reality, the vast size and scope of the Empire meant that thousands of religions were practiced across its vast territory. The [Seswenna sector](/wiki/Seswenna_sector "Seswenna sector") alone had over three hundred distinct religions with active practitioners, all officially recognized by the local Imperial administrator. [Chief of the Imperial Navy](/wiki/Chief_of_the_Imperial_Navy "Chief of the Imperial Navy") [Conan Antonio Motti](/wiki/Conan_Antonio_Motti "Conan Antonio Motti") himself claimed to be a "man of faith," and believed that Imperial unity could only be strengthened through cooperative and constructive dialogue among citizens following diverse spiritual traditions.[[274]](#cite_note-WDSTKH-274) Underground religions surrounding the extinct Jedi such as the [Church of the Force](/wiki/Church_of_the_Force "Church of the Force") and the [Guardians of the Whills](/wiki/Guardians_of_the_Whills "Guardians of the Whills") continued to exist despite their perilous closeness to the Jedi of old.[[17]](#cite_note-TFA_VD-17)[[4]](#cite_note-R1VD-4)

### Slavery[]

:   "*We have a surplus of slave labor—but what to do with it? Could the Wookiees be farmed for their meat? Presently it's stringy and tough, but maybe if they could be fattened up, or modified in some way—crossbred with another species, perhaps, like the Talz.*"
:   ―Commandant [Theodane Sardo](/wiki/Theodane_Sardo "Theodane Sardo")[[7]](#cite_note-Aftermath_LD-7)

The Empire's rise saw the gradual repeal of Republic anti-[slavery](/wiki/Slavery "Slavery") laws.[[223]](#cite_note-Thrawn-223) Species such as the Wookiees were declared [non-sentient](/wiki/Sentience "Sentience"). Subsequently much of the Imperial war machine was built on the shoulders of the enslaved Wookiee population, who saw their homeworld of Kashyyyk ecologically devastated.[[7]](#cite_note-Aftermath_LD-7)

Within the Empire, non-humans were routinely subjugated, with many sent to numerous slave-labor camps across the galaxy, one of the most infamous being the [spice mines of Kessel](/wiki/Spice_mines_of_Kessel "Spice mines of Kessel"), where Wookiee slaves, prized for their strength, were sent to mine the valuable spice located in the planet's interior. It was a literal death sentence for many, with an expected survival time of three months.[[52]](#cite_note-Rebels_Visual_Guide-52) Humanoid species often survived longer, ranging from one to two years in the mines.[[139]](#cite_note-Heir-139)

Abusive and exploitative, the Empire forcibly relocated settlers and pressed them into Imperial factory work. Resisting could see one's family kidnapped and killed.[[272]](#cite_note-Inferno_Squad-272) Unemployment in strategic resource systems was declared unlawful.[[90]](#cite_note-A_New_Dawn-90) On Ryloth, isolated settlements often existed with little or no knowledge about the Empire at large, with those same camps oftentimes being disbanded and their inhabitants relocated to slave-labor camps when needed. Escaped slaves or displaced persons often made up these camps, similar to Tarkintown on Lothal.[[69]](#cite_note-Lords_of_the_Sith-69) Those that resisted Imperial rule could see their whole planet devastated and species reduced to near-extinction, such as the reptilian [Bodach'i](/wiki/Bodach%27i "Bodach'i"), who were forced to work in spice mines on planets such as Kerev Doi.[[87]](#cite_note-Lost_Stars-87)

## Astrography[]

### Administrative divisions[]

:   "*Was it not you who suggested the creation of oversectors and oversector governance as a means of enhancing our control?*"
:   ―Emperor Palpatine, to Wilhuff Tarkin[[9]](#cite_note-Tarkin-9)

While the Empire utilized the senators of the Imperial Senate to maintain control of their respective systems, control was gradually given over to Imperial sector and planetary governors, or Moffs. Grand Moffs were charged with overseeing control of oversectors, which comprised numerous sectors,[[9]](#cite_note-Tarkin-9) and the Imperial Navy was organized into sector fleets.[[110]](#cite_note-Legacy-110) Rather than direct annexation, many of the Empire's territories were controlled through puppet states, alliances, and protectorates, most notably the Corporate Sector.[[49]](#cite_note-Twilight_Company-49)[[255]](#cite_note-DB-255)

The local governing bodies that were in the Imperial Senate, to which had autonomy were downgraded to a mostly ceremonial and powerless role,[[45]](#cite_note-Leia-45) as were the senators they sent, who all served under a Moff's oversight.[[69]](#cite_note-Lords_of_the_Sith-69)

On the border of the Mid Rim and Outer Rim Territories, an invisible boundary was considered the "front line" against the lawlessness of the Outer Rim.[[49]](#cite_note-Twilight_Company-49) The Imperial sphere of influence ended shortly before reaching [Hutt Space](/wiki/Hutt_Space "Hutt Space"), resulting in its reputation as a haven for smugglers, bounty hunters and other denizens of the galaxy.[[137]](#cite_note-Smuggler's_Run-137)

The Empire also maintained strategic resource systems, in which industrial surveillance, heightened security measures and higher work quotas were in effect, and were often placed under the supervision of influential barons, moguls and efficiency experts.[[90]](#cite_note-A_New_Dawn-90)

### Early holdings and expansionism[]

:   "*You can stand to see the Imperial flag reign across the galaxy?*"
:   ―Saw Gerrera, to Jyn Erso[[132]](#cite_note-RO-132)

As the successor state to the Galactic Republic, the Galactic Empire's authority spanned most of the known galaxy,[[3]](#cite_note-Episode_III-3) with the Core Worlds housing some of the richest and most affluent planets in the Empire, with gradual economic decline and lawlessness appearing the further one ventured from the Core. While the Emperor planned to claim the Outer Rim, the logistical complexities of such a feat soon became apparent. Many of the exoplanets were too rough, wild, or strange to ever be brought under Imperial yoke. Thus, many were relegated to hold meager garrisons or host temporary military excursions. As a result, exploitation, weapons testing and military installations dotted the Outer Systems, while Imperials often came for the drinking, smoking, gambling, or black-market goods.[[16]](#cite_note-Aftermath-16)

Located in the Galactic Empire was the [extragalactic](/wiki/Extragalactic "Extragalactic") holding of [Kamino](/wiki/Kamino "Kamino"),[[275]](#cite_note-AftermathBB-275) which was in a [star system](/wiki/Kamino_system "Kamino system") that straggled south of the [Rishi Maze](/wiki/Rishi_Maze "Rishi Maze") satellite galaxy and beyond the larger galaxy.[[29]](#cite_note-Episode_II-29) Early into its reign, the Empire expanded into the Outer Rim, creating a presence that was far greater than what former Padawan Ahsoka Tano had expected; after fleeing from the suddenly occupied small moon of Raada, which the Imperials had taken over in order to exploit its farmland, she found that every star system she passed through had been taken over, with a controlling Imperial presence installed in each. As Tano observed, such Imperial holdings were not merely bases constructed to look over local governments, but oppressive extensions of the Empire, controlling the local resources and populations without any concern for their needs nor personal rights.[[51]](#cite_note-Ahsoka-51) A devout Imperial, meanwhile, would allege the Empire improved every star system it entered with—as "the Client" put it—trade, safety, prosperity, and "peace."[[276]](#cite_note-Chapter_7-276) However, large scale Imperial peace came at the cost of one's personal freedoms[[277]](#cite_note-Chapter_15-277) and said "secruity" depended greatly on punishing whatever it was that the Empire deemed to be "wrong."[[243]](#cite_note-Narkina_5-243)

Seeking the source of the dark side, the Empire established numerous labs and communications stations on distant moons and asteroids beyond known space, with Emperor Palpatine believing his power was drawn from beyond the galaxy.[[16]](#cite_note-Aftermath-16) The Imperial Survey Corps helped Palpatine chart the unexplored regions of the galaxy.[[278]](#cite_note-Escape-278) Palpatine maintained relations with the Chiss Ascendancy, a regional power located within the Unknown Regions through its ambassador, Mitth'raw'nuruodo, better known as Thrawn. Palpatine accepted Thrawn as his adviser on matters involving the Unknown Regions, and hoped they would both fight potential future threats from the Unknown Regions.[[223]](#cite_note-Thrawn-223)

### Retreat and collapse[]

:   "*The factories of Kuat have been bombed into submission, and the shipyards of Xa Fel, Anadeen, and Turco Prime are all either contested or already lost. But the Outer Rim will be our savior—and it will be the strangling cord we tie around the neck of the New Republic. We already have three worlds under our sway there: Zhadalene, Korrus, and Belladoon.*"
:   ―Gallius Rax, to the Shadow Council[[7]](#cite_note-Aftermath_LD-7)

Following the Battle of Endor, the Galactic Empire steadily began to shrink, losing numerous worlds to the recently formed New Republic, with Imperial assets and academies on worlds such as [Uyter](/wiki/Uyter "Uyter") destroyed in bloody warfare. With its losses and failures, the Empire retreated to numerous fallback positions on strategically unimportant worlds such as Naalol, often drawing the New Republic into long and indecisive conflicts, forestalling its slow push toward the Core Worlds. Despite these efforts, the Republic had already established its capital on Chandrila, a planet located within the Core.[[16]](#cite_note-Aftermath-16) The Empire made three successive sieges to retake the Mid Rim world of Naboo, birthplace of Palpatine and thus an influential rallying point for the Empire's shattered forces, but failed.[[87]](#cite_note-Lost_Stars-87)

A few months after Endor, the Imperial Future Council met on Akiva, a planet in a sector of the Outer Rim still under Imperial control.[[16]](#cite_note-Aftermath-16) Roughly two months after the Battle on Akiva, the Galactic Empire's territorial possessions were rapidly shrinking and described as a "patchwork quilt" by Grand Admiral Rae Sloane. Numerous systems left the Empire or waged their own resistance movements, declared their independence, and established their own fiefdoms or joined the New Republic. Criminal syndicates flourished in this atmosphere of conflict, especially the reptilian pirate Eleodie Maracavanya, who had captured the Super Star Destroyer *Annihilator* and used it to forge her own criminal empire. Various moffs and governors rebelled against the Empire, while more and more people asked what exactly the Empire *was*. Agencies, personnel, and whole planetary systems started to drift apart, each adopting differing tactics and methods for combating the New Republic, and each other.[[7]](#cite_note-Aftermath_LD-7)

By this time, the Empire had already lost numerous systems to the New Republic's lighting-fast strikes, and factionalism had begun to scar any attempts to reclaim lost territories. The New Republic had already made headway into the Core Worlds. The last sector of the Outer Rim under Imperial control was a thin region of space known as the [Exterior](/wiki/Exterior "Exterior"), along with the planets [Zhadalene](/wiki/Zhadalene "Zhadalene"), [Korrus](/wiki/Korrus "Korrus"), and [Belladoon](/wiki/Belladoon "Belladoon"). With the shipyards of Kuat, Xa Fel, Anadeen, and Turco Prime having already been lost or contested, Rax planned to use the Empire's last foothold in the Outer Rim as a "strangling cord" to tie around the New Republic. While the Chandrila terror attack demoralized the New Republic, it failed to turn the tide of the war against the Empire, which soon after lost Kashyyyk following an uprising led by Han Solo and Chewbacca.[[7]](#cite_note-Aftermath_LD-7)

After their defeat at Jakku and the signing of the Galactic Concordance, some Imperial warships began jumping into the Unknown Regions to escape the prying eyes of the New Republic. This was made easier since parts of the Unknown Regions had previously been explored by military scout ships surveying star systems and blazing hyperspace routes known only to a select few.[[17]](#cite_note-TFA_VD-17)

## Behind the scenes[]

### Development[]

The Galactic Empire first appeared as the main antagonist of the first *[Star Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars "Star Wars")* movie, [*Star Wars*: Episode IV *A New Hope*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_IV_A_New_Hope "Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope"), in 1977, where it was named the "evil Galactic Empire" in the opening crawl.[[2]](#cite_note-Episode_IV-2) The Empire's origins and role in the *Star Wars* universe were subsequently expanded by various [Expanded Universe](/wiki/Star_Wars_Legends "Star Wars Legends") literature and media over the next four decades. Following the [Lucasfilm Story Group](/wiki/Lucasfilm_Story_Group "Lucasfilm Story Group")'s decision in May 2014 to reboot the *Star Wars* universe.[[279]](#cite_note-279) Financial engineering professor Zachary Feinstein calculated that the hypothetical GDP of the Galactic Empire would be 4.6 sextillion per year.[[280]](#cite_note-Its_a_Trap:_Emperor_Palpatine's_Poison_Pill-280)

According to the author [Jason Fry](/wiki/Jason_Fry "Jason Fry"), the Galactic Empire in the newly established canonical universe was not openly xenophobic and misogynistic, unlike the Legends version. However, he acknowledged that some of the Empire's most devoted supporters were xenophobes, like his character [Janus Fhurek](/wiki/Janus_Fhurek "Janus Fhurek"), a minor antagonist in his 2014 junior novel *[Servants of the Empire: Edge of the Galaxy](/wiki/Servants_of_the_Empire:_Edge_of_the_Galaxy "Servants of the Empire: Edge of the Galaxy")*. In his view, the presence of prominent Imperial female characters in [John Jackson Miller](/wiki/John_Jackson_Miller "John Jackson Miller")'s novel [*A New Dawn*](/wiki/A_New_Dawn_(novel) "A New Dawn (novel)") and *Star Wars Rebels* precluded the idea of a misogynistic Empire.[[281]](#cite_note-Wired_for_the_Classics-281) Pro-human xenophobia within the Imperial Military, government bureaucracy,[[223]](#cite_note-Thrawn-223) and society[[26]](#cite_note-TROS_VD-26) has since been confirmed[[223]](#cite_note-Thrawn-223) in reference guides like *[Star Wars Rebels: The Visual Guide](/wiki/Star_Wars_Rebels:_The_Visual_Guide "Star Wars Rebels: The Visual Guide")*[[52]](#cite_note-Rebels_Visual_Guide-52) and *[Star Wars Rebels: Visual Guide: Epic Battles](/wiki/Star_Wars_Rebels:_Visual_Guide:_Epic_Battles "Star Wars Rebels: Visual Guide: Epic Battles")*,[[273]](#cite_note-Epic_Battles-273) and novels like [*Thrawn*](/wiki/Thrawn_(novel) "Thrawn (novel)"). *Thrawn* clarified that Imperials were not officially allowed to disrespect non-humans, with General Orders to Imperial cadets outlining that, but Imperials did so all the same.[[223]](#cite_note-Thrawn-223) Canonical sources ultimately confirmed that human superiority was an intentional push from the Empire[[7]](#cite_note-Aftermath_LD-7) under the High Human cultural model.[[26]](#cite_note-TROS_VD-26) *[Star Wars: The Rise and Fall of the Galactic Empire](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Rise_and_Fall_of_the_Galactic_Empire "Star Wars: The Rise and Fall of the Galactic Empire")* went onto suggest that misogyny did exist within the Empire as well.[[11]](#cite_note-Rise_Fall-11)

### Inspirations[]

The Republic's transformation into the Empire is perhaps modeled after the transformation of the [Roman Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Republic "wikipedia:Roman Republic") into the [Roman Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Empire "wikipedia:Roman Empire"); the Roman Republic was transformed because of war, infighting, and two of its leaders, [Julius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julius_Caesar "wikipedia:Julius Caesar") and [Augustus Caesar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augustus "wikipedia:Augustus"). Other reasons for the transition were based on the transformation of the [First French Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_French_Republic "wikipedia:First French Republic") into the [French Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_French_Empire "wikipedia:First French Empire") by [Napoleon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napoleon_I "wikipedia:Napoleon I") (after a coup), and the [Weimar Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weimar_Republic "wikipedia:Weimar Republic") into the Third Reich. Lucas, during the 2005 Cannes film festival, implied that the similarities between these historical elements, and to a lesser extent America's fighting in the 2003 Iraq War, were deliberate as part of Lucas' philosophy that democracies tend to be turned into dictatorships at the people's willing support, a philosophy that he implied had stemmed from American involvement in the Vietnam War.[[282]](#cite_note-'Sith'_invites_Bush_Comparisons-282)[[283]](#cite_note-USA_Today-283)

Similar to the Soviet Union under Stalin (specifically the aftermath of Stalin's death), as soon as Palpatine met his first demise at the Battle of Endor, various insergencies throughout the Empire were attempted before being put down by the Imperials. One insergency in particular, the [Coruscant Uprising](/wiki/Coruscant_uprising "Coruscant uprising"), had notable similarities to the [Hungarian Revolution of 1956](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1956 "wikipedia:Hungarian Revolution of 1956") that commenced shortly after Stalin's death. On a related note, series creator George Lucas cited that Emperor Palpatine's arrival on the Death Star in [*Return of the Jedi*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_VI_Return_of_the_Jedi "Star Wars: Episode VI Return of the Jedi") was based of the military parades in "May Day" in what was at the time Soviet Russia.[[284]](#cite_note-Palpatine's_debut_inspiration-284) George Lucas, however, indicated in *[The Making of Star Wars: The Definitive Story Behind the Original Film](/wiki/The_Making_of_Star_Wars:_The_Definitive_Story_Behind_the_Original_Film "The Making of Star Wars: The Definitive Story Behind the Original Film")*, *[The Making of Return of the Jedi](/wiki/The_Making_of_Return_of_the_Jedi "The Making of Return of the Jedi")*, the *Revenge of the Sith* commentary, as well as the Empire of Dreams and the Cannes Festival showing of *Revenge of the Sith* that the Galactic Empire was primarily based in part on the American forces during the Vietnam War, when citing that the Ewoks and Rebel Alliance were based on the Viet Cong and also claiming his primary
inspiration for the Empire's ruler, Palpatine, was then-president Nixon, and also implied in *The Making of Star Wars* that the Empire was essentially American in 1983 (ten years after he started writing the drafts for *Star Wars*) where "Nixonian gangsters" assassinated the Emperor and used a rigged election to obtain power as well as exploited various groups to maintain power as deliberately letting crime escalate to such an extent that people would welcome a total control police state.[[285]](#cite_note-Nixonian_Gangsters-285)

Lucas himself was quoted in a interview conducted in 2005 at Skywalker Ranch that: "It was really about the Vietnam War, and that was the period where Nixon was trying to run for a [second] term, which got me to thinking historically about how do democracies get turned into dictatorships? Because the democracies aren't overthrown; they're given away." He further opined in the interview that "no matter who you look at in history, the story is always the same, that's what's eerie. It was a little eerie that things have developed the way they have."[[286]](#cite_note-chicagotribune-286) He also had envisioned the Empire as being based on Vietnam War-ere America (and by extension, the Rebel Alliance being based on the [Viet Cong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viet_Cong "wikipedia:Viet Cong")) as early as when he penned the storyline back in 1973, in part due to Star Wars itself being a continuation of a thematic trilogy decrying American involvement in Vietnam, claiming that his intended story draft when pitching it that the story was about "a [technological empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_of_America "wikipedia:United States of America") going after a [small band of freedom fighters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viet_Cong "wikipedia:Viet Cong")," which had stemmed from his role in the development of the film [*Apocalypse Now*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apocalypse_Now_(film) "wikipedia:Apocalypse Now (film)") earlier.[[287]](#cite_note-New_York_Post-287)[[288]](#cite_note-288)[[289]](#cite_note-Making_of_Star_Wars-289)[[285]](#cite_note-Nixonian_Gangsters-285) In an interview for TIME magazine regarding the then-upcoming Star Wars: Episode II Attack of the Clones regarding the connection of the Empire and the Republic, Lucas also implied that, besides Nixon, another influence on the Empire had been the [Kennedy family](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kennedy_family "wikipedia:Kennedy family").[[290]](#cite_note-Dark_Victory-290)

[↑](#cite_ref-Mando_Chapter_23_date_24-0) *[Star Wars: Timelines](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Timelines "Star Wars: Timelines")* dates the events of "[Chapter 1: The Mandalorian](/wiki/Chapter_1:_The_Mandalorian "Chapter 1: The Mandalorian")" of [*The Mandalorian* Season One](/wiki/The_Mandalorian_Season_One "The Mandalorian Season One") to [9 ABY](/wiki/9_ABY "9 ABY"). In addition, [SWInsider](/wiki/Star_Wars_Insider "Star Wars Insider") "[A Certain Point of View](/wiki/A_Certain_Point_of_View_(department) "A Certain Point of View (department)")" — [*Star Wars Insider* 228](/wiki/Star_Wars_Insider_228 "Star Wars Insider 228") also dates "[Part Seven: Dreams and Madness](/wiki/Part_Seven:_Dreams_and_Madness "Part Seven: Dreams and Madness")" to nine [years](/wiki/Standard_year "Standard year") after the events of [*Star Wars*: Episode IV *A New Hope*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_IV_A_New_Hope "Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope"), which corresponds to 9 [ABY](/wiki/%27ABY-BBY%27_dating_system "'ABY-BBY' dating system") per *Timelines*. "Part Seven: Dreams and Madness" takes place after the [liberation of Mandalore](/wiki/Liberation_of_Mandalore "Liberation of Mandalore"), which is the main event depicted in "[Chapter 23: The Spies](/wiki/Chapter_23:_The_Spies "Chapter 23: The Spies")" and "[Chapter 24: The Return](/wiki/Chapter_24:_The_Return "Chapter 24: The Return")," the final two episodes of [*The Mandalorian* Season Three](/wiki/The_Mandalorian_Season_Three "The Mandalorian Season Three"). Therefore, Seasons One through Three of *[Star Wars: The Mandalorian](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Mandalorian "Star Wars: The Mandalorian")*, the latter of which includes "[Chapter 23: The Spies](/wiki/Chapter_23:_The_Spies "Chapter 23: The Spies")," must all be set in 9 ABY as well. 25. ↑ [25.0](#cite_ref-Mando_Chapter_23_25-0) [25.1](#cite_ref-Mando_Chapter_23_25-1) [25.2](#cite_ref-Mando_Chapter_23_25-2) [25.3](#cite_ref-Mando_Chapter_23_25-3) [The-Mandalorian-logo](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Mandalorian "Star Wars: The Mandalorian") *[Star Wars: The Mandalorian](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Mandalorian "Star Wars: The Mandalorian")* — "[Chapter 23: The Spies](/wiki/Chapter_23:_The_Spies "Chapter 23: The Spies")" 26. ↑ [26.0](#cite_ref-TROS_VD_26-0) [26.1](#cite_ref-TROS_VD_26-1) [26.2](#cite_ref-TROS_VD_26-2) [26.3](#cite_ref-TROS_VD_26-3) *[Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker: The Visual Dictionary](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Rise_of_Skywalker:_The_Visual_Dictionary "Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker: The Visual Dictionary")* 27. In "The Eye," [Jayhold Beehaz](/wiki/Jayhold_Beehaz "Jayhold Beehaz") notes the Imperial-approved viewing festival was established a [decade](/wiki/Standard_decade "Standard decade") prior, placing the beginning of that event in [15 BBY](/wiki/15_BBY "15 BBY"). 73. [↑](#cite_ref-Date_187-0) *[Star Wars: Timelines](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Timelines "Star Wars: Timelines")* dates the events of "[Chapter 1: The Mandalorian](/wiki/Chapter_1:_The_Mandalorian "Chapter 1: The Mandalorian")" of [*The Mandalorian* Season One](/wiki/The_Mandalorian_Season_One "The Mandalorian Season One") to [9 ABY](/wiki/9_ABY "9 ABY"). In addition, [SWInsider](/wiki/Star_Wars_Insider "Star Wars Insider") "[A Certain Point of View](/wiki/A_Certain_Point_of_View_(department) "A Certain Point of View (department)")" — [*Star Wars Insider* 228](/wiki/Star_Wars_Insider_228 "Star Wars Insider 228") also dates "[Part Seven: Dreams and Madness](/wiki/Part_Seven:_Dreams_and_Madness "Part Seven: Dreams and Madness")" to nine [years](/wiki/Standard_year "Standard year") after the events of [*Star Wars*: Episode IV *A New Hope*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_IV_A_New_Hope "Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope"), which corresponds to 9 [ABY](/wiki/%27ABY-BBY%27_dating_system "'ABY-BBY' dating system") per *Timelines*. "Part Seven: Dreams and Madness" takes place after the [liberation of Mandalore](/wiki/Liberation_of_Mandalore "Liberation of Mandalore"), which is the main event depicted in "[Chapter 23: The Spies](/wiki/Chapter_23:_The_Spies "Chapter 23: The Spies")" and "[Chapter 24: The Return](/wiki/Chapter_24:_The_Return "Chapter 24: The Return")," the final two episodes of [*The Mandalorian* Season Three](/wiki/The_Mandalorian_Season_Three "The Mandalorian Season Three"). Therefore, Seasons One through Three of *[Star Wars: The Mandalorian](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Mandalorian "Star Wars: The Mandalorian")* must all be set in 9 ABY as well. 188. [↑](#cite_ref-'Sith'_invites_Bush_Comparisons_282-0)  [Premium-Era-real](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/0e/Premium-Era-real.png/revision/latest?cb=20241019125517) [*Revenge of the Sith* invites Bush Comparisons, page 2](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/sith-invites-bush-comparisons/2) on CBSNews.com: "Lucas said he patterned his story after historical transformations from freedom to fascism, never figuring when he started his prequel trilogy in the late 1990s that current events might parallel his space fantasy. "As you go through history, I didn't think it was going to get quite this close. So it's just one of those recurring things," Lucas said at a Cannes news conference. "I hope this doesn't come tru in our country." […] "Maybe the film will waken people to the situation," Lucas joked. […] "When I wrote it, [the 2003 Iraq war] didn't exist," Lucas said laughing. "We were just funding Saddam Hussein and giving him weapons of mass destruction. We didn't think of him as an enemy at that time. We were going after Iran and using him as our surrogate, just as we were doing in Vietnam. […] The parallels between what we did in Vietnam and what we're doing in Iraq now are unbelievable." The prequel trilogy is based on a back-story outline Lucas created in the mid-1970s for the original three "Star Wars" movies, so the themes percolated out of the Vietnam War and the Nixon-Watergate era, he said. Lucas began researching how democracies can turn into dictatorships with full consent of the electorate. In Ancient Rome, "why did the senate after killing Caesar turn around and give the government to his nephew?" Lucas said. "Why did France after they got rid of the king and that whole system turn around and give it to Napoleon? It's the same thing with Germany and Hitler." "You sort of see these recurring themes where a democracy turns itself into a dictatorship, and it always seems to happen kind of in the same way, with the same kinds of issues, and threats from the outside, needing more control. A democratic body, a senate, not being able to function properly because everybody's squabbling, there's corruption."" ([backup link](https://web.archive.org/web/20210227045528/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/sith-invites-bush-comparisons/2) archived on [February 27](/wiki/February_27 "February 27"), [2021](/wiki/2021 "2021")) 283. [↑](#cite_ref-USA_Today_283-0)  [Premium-Era-real](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/0e/Premium-Era-real.png/revision/latest?cb=20241019125517) [Lucas: 'Star Wars' isn't Iraq wars](http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2005-05-15-cannes-lucas_x.htm) on USAToday.com ([backup link](https://web.archive.org/web/20210227022457/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2005-05-15-cannes-lucas_x.htm) archived on [February 27](/wiki/February_27 "February 27"), [2021](/wiki/2021 "2021")) 284. [↑](#cite_ref-Palpatine's_debut_inspiration_284-0) [*Star Wars*: Episode IV *A New Hope*](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_IV_A_New_Hope "Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope") [home video release](/wiki/Star_Wars_home_video_releases "Star Wars home video releases") 285. ↑ [285.0](#cite_ref-Nixonian_Gangsters_285-0) [285.1](#cite_ref-Nixonian_Gangsters_285-1) *The Making of Star Wars*, pages 7-8; 17 "I started to work on Star Wars rather then continue Apocalypse Now. I had worked on Apocalypse Now for about four years and I had very strong feelings about it. I wanted to do it, but could not get it off the ground... A lot of my interest in Apocalypse Now was carried over into Star Wars. I figured I couldn't make that film because it was about the Vietnam War, so I would essentially deal with some of the same interesting concepts that I was going to use and convert them into space fantasy, so you'd have essentially a large technological empire going after a small group of freedom fighters or human beings [...] a small independent country like North Vietnam threatened by a neighbor or provincial rebellion, instigated by gangsters aided by empire. [...] The Empire is like America ten years from now, after Nixonian gangsters assassinated the Emperor and were elevated to power in a rigged election; created civil disorder by instigating race riots aiding rebel groups and allowing the crime rate to rise to the point where a 'total control' police state was welcomed by the people. Then the people were exploited with high taxes, utility and transport costs. Gangsters, a cartel made up of power companies, transport companies & crime organizations. Other companies had to pay bribes to stay in business. They increased the crime rate by slowing down the system of justice and punishment." 286. [↑](#cite_ref-Dark_Victory_290-0) [Premium-Era-real](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/starwars/images/0/0e/Premium-Era-real.png/revision/latest?cb=20241019125517) [Dark Victory](http://www.time.com/time/sampler/article/0,8599,232440,00.html) on Time Magazine: "I'm more on the liberal side of things," [George Lucas] says. "I grew up in San Francisco in the '60s, and my positions are sort of shaped by that … If you look back 30 years ago, there were certain issues with the Kennedys, with Richard Nixon, that focused my interest." Lucas's own geopolitics can sound pretty bleak: "All democracies turn into dictatorships-but not by coup. The people give their democracy to a dictator, whether it's Julius Caesar or Napoleon or Adolf Hitler. Ultimately, the general population goes along with the idea … What kinds of things push people and institutions into this direction?" ([backup link](https://web.archive.org/web/20020423000824/http://www.time.com/time/sampler/article/0,8599,232440,00.html) archived on [April 23](/wiki/April_23 "April 23"), [2002](/wiki/2002 "2002")) |
